newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada consortium plans first native-owned bank.
newsitem.headline: Canada consortium plans first native-owned bank.

text.p: A Canadian bank and a regional Indian group said on Monday they planned to form the country's first native-owned bank to help Canada's aboriginal people become more financially self-sufficient.
The First Nations Bank of Canada is expected to begin operating in Saskatchewan in late 1996 -- pending approval from federal regulators.
The group plans to expand across Canada with a fully array of banking services offered to aboriginal and non-aboriginal customers.

"We need to grow in the area of finance and this is a step toward our own self-determination as First Nations peoples," Roy Bird, chairman of the Saskatchewan Indian Equity Foundation Inc. (SIEF), said in a telephone interview.
The consortium includes the SIEF, the Federation of Saskatchewan Indians Inc. and the Toronto-Dominion Bank, Canada's fifth largest bank.
Toronto-Dominion is investing C$8 million ($5.8 million) in start-up capital with the SIEF providing an additional C$2 million ($1.5 million).
SIEF said its 75 percent share of the operating profit will be reinvested in the bank. The group also plans a share issue.
Bird said common shares in the new bank will be sold to aboriginal investors only. Preferred shares will be offered to both aboriginal and non-aboriginal investors.
He said the bank will be entirely aboriginally owned and controlled within 10 years.

"We will probably follow the same format as other banks, but the advantage we have is that we have a better understanding of aboriginal communities and of the difficulty that some of our people have in obtaining credit," Bird said.
The idea for the First Nations Bank was born in the early 1980s when the SIEF was formed as Canada's first aboriginal capital corporation.
In the past 15 years, SIEF has loaned more than C$30 million ($22 million) to Saskatchewan-based First Nations businesses with a loan loss rate of just over 1 percent.
But SIEF has been restricted to term lending under Canada's Bank Act, which regulates the country's financial services industry.
By tying up with Toronto-Dominion, the new bank can offer an array of banking services, including credit cards, checking, savings and other deposit accounts and a range of lending options.
"We're bringing that to the table and the (SIEF) are bringing the customers," John Leckie, Toronto-Dominion's senior vice-president of business banking services, said.
